title: How to Troubleshoot a Mobile Hotspot (When Itâ€™s Not Working)

steps.title: Your reception or cellular data connection may be poor.
steps.content: Your reception or cellular data connection may be poor. Make sure you are getting at least 2 bars of signal strength on your mobile device. Try browsing the internet on your mobile device. If the internet seems slow and unreliable, you may not be getting a good cellular data connection. You may be in an area that has poor coverage, or the network may be congested. You may need to move to another area or wait and try again later.

steps.title: You may be too far away from your mobile hotspot.
steps.content: You may be too far away from your mobile hotspot. Ensure you keep all devices connected to your mobile hotspot near your mobile device. The Wi-Fi signal degrades the further away you are from your mobile hotspot. Stay within 15 feet of your hotspot. [1] X Research source

steps.title: You may have exceeded your data plan for the month.
steps.content: You may have exceeded your data plan for the month. Some mobile data plans provide you with a limited amount of data per month. Contact your wireless carrier and check what kind of cellular data plan you have. They can also tell you how much data you have used. If you have already used your monthly data, you may be able to upgrade to an unlimited plan or a plan that allows more data usage. Dial 611 on your phone to contact your wireless carrier.

steps.title: Your hotspot may not be turned on.
steps.content: Your hotspot may not be turned on. This may seem basic, but it's worth checking. Use one of the following steps to make sure your mobile hotspot is turned on: [2] X Research source

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Connections (Samsung Galaxy) or Network & Internet (stock Android). Tap Mobile Hotstop and Teathering . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Mobile Hotspot" is on.

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Open the Settings app. Tap Cellular (or Personal Hotspot depending on your version of iOS). Tap Personal Hotspot . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Allow others to join" is turned on.

steps.title: You may not have the right password.
steps.content: You may not have the right password. When connecting to your mobile hotspot, make sure you are entering the correct SSID password. It's possible you may have entered the incorrect password on the mobile device that is transmitting the mobile hotspot. Use one of the following steps to check your mobile hotspot password:

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Connections (Samsung Galaxy) or Network & Internet (stock Android). Tap Mobile Hotstop and Teathering . Tap Mobile Hotspot . Ensure the password is correct.

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Open the Settings app. Tap Cellular (or Personal Hotspot depending on your version of iOS). Tap Personal Hotspot . Ensure the password is correct.

steps.title: You might have mobile data turned off.
steps.content: You might have mobile data turned off. Both iPhone and Android devices allow you to turn off mobile data to prevent you from using data from your cellular service plan. If mobile data is turned off, you won't be able to use a mobile hotspot unless your mobile device is connected to Wi-Fi. Use one of the following steps to check to make sure mobile data is turned on:

steps.title: Stock Android:
steps.content: Stock Android: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Network & Internet . Tap Internet . Tap the gear icon next to your mobile carrier (or SIMs if you have a Pixel phone). Ensure the toggle switch next to "Mobile Data" is turned on. If it's already turned on, turn it off and wait 30 seconds. Then turn it back on to reset your connection.

steps.title: Samsung Galaxy:
steps.content: Samsung Galaxy: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Connections . Tap Data usage . Ensure toggle switch next to "Mobile data" is turned on. If it's already turned on, turn it off and wait 30 seconds. Then turn it back on to reset your connection.

steps.title: iPhone and iPad:
steps.content: iPhone and iPad: [3] X Research source Open the Settings app. Tap Cellular data or Mobile data . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Cellular data" or "Mobile data" is turned on. If it's already turned on, turn it off and wait 30 seconds. Then turn it back on to reset your connection.

steps.title: There may be a minor glitch in your software.
steps.content: There may be a minor glitch in your software. You can usually fix minor glitches in your software by restarting your device. Use one of the following steps to do so:

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: Press and hold the Power button until the Power menu appears. Then tap Restart .

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Press and hold the Side/Sleep button and either Volume button until the power slider appears. Drag the slider to turn off your phone. Wait 30 seconds then press and hold the Power button to turn it back on.

steps.title: Your phone or tablet doesn't have the latest updates.
steps.content: Your phone or tablet doesn't have the latest updates. The latest updates can patch out bugs and security flaws in the system. To keep your phone or tablet running smoothly, make sure you keep your mobile device updated . Use one of the following steps to update your mobile device :

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Software Updates (on stock Android, this is under System ). Tap Download and install .

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Open the Settings app. Tap General . Tap Software Update . Tap Download and install .

steps.title: Low power mode may be preventing your device from connecting.
steps.content: Low power mode may be preventing your device from connecting. Low Power mode on iPhone/iPad and Battery Saver mode on Android devices is meant to limit nonessential functions in order to save battery power. Sometimes, this may interfere with features you want to use, such as your mobile hotspot. Use one of the following steps to turn off Low Power or Battery Saver mode: [4] X Research source [5] X Research source

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Battery . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Battery Saver" or "Power Saving" (Samsung Galaxy) is turned off.

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Open the Settings app. Tap Battery . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Low Power Mode" is turned off.

steps.title: There may be a minor glitch in your internet connection.
steps.content: There may be a minor glitch in your internet connection. Another quick way to fix minor internet connection issues is to turn Wi-Fi off and then back on. This will refresh your device's internet connection. Use one of the following steps to reset your Wi-Fi:

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Then tap the Wi-Fi icon, which resembles arching lines over a dot. Wait 30 seconds and then turn it back on.

steps.title: iPhone and iPad:
steps.content: iPhone and iPad: Swipe down from the upper-right corner to open the Control Center. Then tap the Wi-Fi icon, which resembles arching lines over a dot. Wait 30 seconds and then turn it back on.

steps.title: Your VPN may be slowing your internet connection.
steps.content: Your VPN may be slowing your internet connection. If you are using a VPN, your internet connection may be slow. Try turning your VPN off . Use one of the following steps to do so:

steps.title: Stock Android:
steps.content: Stock Android: [6] X Research source Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Network & internet . Tap the Gear icon next to your VPN. Tap the toggle switch to turn off that VPN.

steps.title: Samsung Galaxy:
steps.content: Samsung Galaxy: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Connections . Tap More connection settings . Tap VPN Tap the toggle switch next to your VPN to turn it off.

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Open the Settings app. Tap General . Tap VPN & Device Management . Tap VPN . Tap the toggle switch next to "Status" to disconnect it.

steps.title: The device you are trying to connect may not be compatible with a 5 GHz band.
steps.content: The device you are trying to connect may not be compatible with a 5 GHz band. A 5 GHz band is usually the default frequency that a mobile hotspot uses. This is a newer and faster frequency. A 2.4 GHz frequency is a little slower, but has greater range. Some older devices may not be compatible with a 5 GHz frequency. Use one of the following steps to change your frequency band on your mobile device: [7] X Research source

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Connections (Samsung Galaxy) or Network & Internet (stock Android). Tap Mobile Hotstop and Teathering . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Mobile Hotspot" is on. Tap Mobile Hotspot . Tap Band or AP Band . Tap 2.4 GHz (stock Android) or drag the slider bar below "Band" to "Compatibility" (Samsung Galaxy).

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Open the Settings app. Tap Cellular (or Personal Hotspot depending on your version of iOS). Tap Personal Hotspot . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Allow others to join" is turned on. Tap the toggle switch next to "Maximize compatibility."

steps.title: USB tethering may give you a better connection.
steps.content: USB tethering may give you a better connection. You don't have to connect to your mobile hotspot using Wi-Fi. You can also use USB tethering to connect to your mobile hotspot. Use one of the following steps to do so:

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: [8] X Research source Connect your phone to your computer using a USB cable. Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap Connections (Samsung Galaxy) or Network & Internet (stock Android). Tap Mobile Hotstop and Teathering . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Mobile Hotspot" is on. Tap the toggle switch next to "USB tethering to turn it on.

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Connect your phone to your computer using a USB or Lightning cable. Open the Settings app. Tap Cellular (or Personal Hotspot depending on your version of iOS). Tap Personal Hotspot . Ensure the toggle switch next to "Allow others to join" is turned on. Tap Trust on your iPhone if prompted.

steps.title: Your internet settings may not be set right.
steps.content: Your internet settings may not be set right. Resetting your network settings will change your internet settings back to their factory defaults. This will not erase any personal data or files on your phone, but it will erase your Wi-Fi connections, password, and Bluetooth pairings. You should do this as a last resort. Use one of the following steps to reset your network settings:

steps.title: Android:
steps.content: Android: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Tap the Gear/Settings icon to open the Settings menu. Tap System (stock Android) or General Management (Samsung Galaxy). Tap Reset Options (stock Android) or Reset (Samsung Galaxy). Tap Reset network settings (stock Android) or Reset Wi-Fi, mobile, and Bluetooth (Samsung Galaxy). Tap Reset settings .

steps.title: iPhone & iPad:
steps.content: iPhone & iPad: Open the Settings app. Tap General . Tap Reset . Tap Reset Network Settings . Tap Reset Network Settings again.
